title: 110_hr1057
content: The "Education Improvement Tax Cut Act" allows for a credit for contributions to charitable organizations providing elementary or secondary school scholarships under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax code allows individuals to receive a credit for qualified scholarship contributions made during the taxable year, capped at $5,000 ($2,500 for married individuals filing separately). Qualified scholarship contributions are defined as cash donations to school tuition organizations. The term 'school tuition organization' refers to an organization that primarily disburses scholarships for elementary and secondary school education. These scholarships must cover expenses up to 12th grade and are excluded from gross income. Contributions for which a credit is allowed cannot be deducted. There is an option to elect for the credit not to apply. A taxpayer can elect to have the section not apply for any taxable year before the 3-year period after the filing deadline. The dollar amount in subsection (b) is adjusted for inflation for taxable years after 2007. The section allows for adjustments in dollar amounts for inflation in taxable years after 2007. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for claiming the credit on Form 1040EZ. Section 25F allows for contributions of and for instructional materials and materials for extracurricular activities. Effective date for amendments is after December 31, 2006. The tax code allows individuals to receive a credit for qualified school materials contributions up to $5,000 per year. Contributions must be designated for elementary or secondary schools to qualify. The tax code allows individuals to receive a credit for contributions of qualified school materials to elementary or secondary schools or school materials organizations. Elementary or secondary school refers to organizations providing education up to the 12th grade. School materials organizations are defined as entities primarily raising funds for elementary education. The organization's purpose is to raise funds for elementary or secondary schools, ensuring that at least 90 percent of their annual disbursements go towards qualified school materials. Qualified school materials include instructional materials, equipment, and resources for schools. The section discusses the denial of double benefits for contributions eligible for a credit, and the option for taxpayers to elect not to apply the credit for a taxable year. Additionally, it mentions a cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years after 2007. Beginning in a calendar year after 2007, the dollar amount in subsection (b) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the taxable year. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for claiming the credit on Form 1040EZ. The dollar amount in subsection (b) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the taxable year. Regulations will be prescribed for claiming the credit on Form 1040EZ. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2006.
